title: 115_hr1629
content: The "Public Safety and Wildlife Protection Act" aims to reduce risks to public safety and harm to animals by prohibiting the import, export, and interstate shipment of steel-jaw leghold traps and Conibear traps. Penalties are outlined for violating these prohibitions. It is illegal to import, export, deliver, or sell steel-jaw leghold traps or Conibear traps in interstate commerce. Violators face civil fines or imprisonment. Violators of the ban on steel-jaw leghold traps or Conibear traps may face fines, imprisonment for up to 2 years, or both. Additionally, they are required to pay all court costs associated with the violation. SEC. 4. REWARDS. The Secretary will pay half of the fine to individuals providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Officers or employees in official capacity are not eligible for rewards. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces this Act and its rules, utilizing personnel and facilities from other agencies. Import and export violations are treated as customs law violations. (c) Forfeiture. Any steel-jaw leghold trap or Conibear trap found in violation of this Act shall be subject to forfeiture to the United States. Under this Act, property subject to forfeiture to the United States for violations of customs laws will be seized and forfeited according to relevant provisions of law. This includes the disposition of property or proceeds, remission or mitigation of forfeitures, and compromise of claims, in line with customs laws enforcement. The Secretary or authorized officers may perform seizures and forfeitures of property under this Act. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators, and cooperation among relevant departments is required for effective enforcement. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "steel-jaw leghold trap" refers to a device designed to capture an animal by snapping closed on its limb, foot, or part thereof, excluding cage traps or live beaver traps. The term "Conibear trap" is defined as a trap powered by torsion springs to kill an animal by snapping its spinal column. The term "steel-jaw leghold trap" captures an animal by snapping on its limb, foot, or part thereof, excluding cage traps or live beaver traps. The term "Conibear trap" kills an animal by snapping its spinal column. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to laws enforced by the United States Customs Service. The term "import" means to bring into the United States. The term "interstate commerce" is defined in section 10 of title 18, United States Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary. The term "Secretary" in the United States Code refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior may create rules to implement the Act, which will become effective one year after its enactment.
